<robsongo@...> writes:

> I think if you look at museum collections in Japan, the answer is there.
> They do not touch anything no matter the condition. If the wrap is coming
> off, it is coming off. They may add something to secure menuki and such to
> keep them in place - typically thread. The same goes with lacquer, it is not
> touched. Thus, the standards for shinsa are the same. I am pretty sure this
> is the case with the NBTHK as well. So, what to do to repair something? If
> you want to keep the piece original and unaltered, you must have all new
> mounts made and you set aside the original pieces. I know this may seem to
> be unreasonable, but those are the very high standards that have been
> maintained at shinsa and in museums. I think the same holds true for antique
> firearms. Re-blued barrels, re-done stocks and what not seriously harm the
> value of the piece. Thus, such alterations should not be done lightly.

So if I were to take the case of my damaged saya... I don't think that
this is particularly important as these things go, but since I have it
on hand it is a useful example.

If I wanted to submit it to shinsa, does the damage mean it won't get a
paper? Or do you accept damaged pieces? 

It was altered, but reversibly so as the pieces screwed off and slipped
off with a bit of effort... so it is just original and beaten up, but
the full set seems to have gone together forever. 

It is probably middle, to slightly more than middle quality, but is
unusual in that the saya is red. 

I understand that red saya were banned on low ranking samurai, along
with other red articles of clothing, so it is unusual for that.

I am pondering this now and since the damage is only to the saya, it
might be that a correct route would be to send in the set of koshirae
together to see if it would paper and so authenticate it as an original
set... quality might get marked down considerably then because of the
damage. But then I could have a replacement made for the damaged
saya. The tsuka looks to have survived pretty intact. 

I have no experience in this stuff, I'm asking for my own education, and
maybe as a possible something-to-do with this set of koshirae.

- darcy
